# Cambridge International AS & A Level  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 194, 201]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 214, 905, 255]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 230, 292]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9709/22  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 310, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Pure Mathematics 2  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2024  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 325, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 393, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 419, 222, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 270, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 806, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 359, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 868, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 606]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 860, 637]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 213, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 380, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 729, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
Use logarithms to show that the equation \(5^{8y} = 6^{7x}\) can be expressed in the form \(y = kx\). Give the value of the constant \(k\) correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 88, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 500, 92]]<|/det|>
A curve has equation \(6\mathrm{e}^{-x}y^{2} + \mathrm{e}^{2x} - 12y + 7 = 0.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 106, 515, 125]]<|/det|>
Find the gradient of the curve at the point \((\ln 3, 2)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 106, 918, 125]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 144, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 75, 702, 92]]<|/det|>
Sketch the graphs of \(y = 1 + \mathrm{e}^{2x}\) and \(y = \left|x - 4\right|\) on the same diagram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 75, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 465, 146, 483]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 465, 437, 483]]<|/det|>
The two graphs meet at the point \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 494, 697, 514]]<|/det|>
Show that the \(x\)-coordinate of \(P\) satisfies the equation \(x = \frac{1}{2}\ln (3 - x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 494, 920, 512]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
Use an iterative formula, based on the equation in part **(b)**, to find the \(x\)-coordinate of \(P\) correct to 3 significant figures. Use an initial value of 0.45 and give the result of each iteration to 5 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 101, 920, 119]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 391, 91]]<|/det|>
The polynomial \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) is defined by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[396, 104, 603, 126]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{p}(x) = a x^{3} + b x^{2} - a x + 8,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 145, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants. It is given that \((x + 2)\) is a factor of \(\mathrm{p}(x)\), and that the remainder is 24 when \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) is divided by \((x - 2)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 192, 146, 210]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 192, 364, 210]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(a\) and \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 193, 920, 211]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 806, 92]]<|/det|>
Factorise \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) and hence show that the equation \(\mathrm{p}(x) = 0\) has exactly one real root.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 475, 186, 494]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 475, 611, 494]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(\mathrm{p}\Big(\frac{1}{2}\mathrm{cos}\mathrm{e}\Theta \Big) = 0\) for \(-90^{\circ}< \theta < 90^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 475, 920, 494]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 69, 92, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[324, 87, 665, 260]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 274, 794, 300]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curves with equations \(y = \sqrt[3]{5x^2 + 7}\) and \(y = \frac{27}{2x + 5}\) for \(x \geqslant 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 298, 393, 318]]<|/det|>
The curves meet at the point (2, 3).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 314, 856, 342]]<|/det|>
Region \(A\) is bounded by the curve \(y = \sqrt[3]{5x^2 + 7}\) and the straight lines \(x = 0\), \(x = 2\) and \(y = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 339, 638, 359]]<|/det|>
Region \(B\) is bounded by the two curves and the straight line \(x = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 369, 144, 388]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 368, 920, 405]]<|/det|>
Use the trapezium rule with two intervals to find an approximation to the area of region \(A\). Give your answer correct to 3 significant figures. [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Find the exact total area of regions \(A\) and \(B\). Give your answer in the form \(k\ln m\), where \(k\) and \(m\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 85, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 432, 181, 451]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[178, 432, 918, 451]]<|/det|>
Deduce an approximation to the area of region \(B\). Give your answer correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 445, 918, 464]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 630, 148, 648]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 630, 920, 664]]<|/det|>
State, with a reason, whether your answer to part **(c)** is an over-estimate or an under-estimate of the area of region \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 648, 920, 666]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 463, 89]]<|/det|>
Express \(4\sin \theta \sin (\theta + 60^{\circ})\) in the form

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 102, 579, 121]]<|/det|>
\[a + R\sin (2\theta -\alpha),\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 588, 152]]<|/det|>
where \(a\) and \(R\) are positive integers and \(0^{\circ} < \alpha < 90^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 134, 917, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 675, 89]]<|/det|>
Hence find the smallest positive value of \(\theta\) satisfying the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 106, 608, 129]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{1}{5} +4\sin \theta \sin (\theta +60^{\circ}) = 0.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 108, 920, 127]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 102, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
If you use the following lined page to complete the answer(s) to any question(s), the question number(s) must be clearly shown.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 73, 562, 88]]<|/det|>
BLANK PAGE
